Title: Contractor project manager leadership style based on path goal theory to support construction sustainability
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sujana, C.M., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Sustainability in construction projects has become an essential issue To implement sustainability in the construction project, trained personnel are needed. However, the temporary projects and the turnover of the project team members remained obstructions in performing these principles. Leadership is a competency that must be possessed by the contractor project manager in leading the project and making sure the construction project sustainability constructing subordinate engagement and organizational learning. Various studies on leadership styles that are suitable to be applied in the construction industry have been carried out in various countries, but in Indonesia, it has not been a concern. This study describes the leadership styles of the project manager uses Path-Goal leadership theory. From the research carried out on projects in Jakarta and Bandung, it was found that project managers in construction projects tend to lead by using achievement oriented style. Short construction project completion times and penalties if the project finish late, both are making PM oriented towards achievement, giving targets to the project team and expecting the best performance from the project team. However, project managers lack trust in subordinates to take decisions (participative). It affected the subordinate engagement at work that needed in supporting construction sustainability. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: construction sustainability; leadership; path goal theory; project manager
Index Keywords: Construction industry; Contractors; Managers; Sustainable development; Construction projects; leadership; Leadership style; Leadership theory; Organizational learning; path goal theory; Project managers; Project team; Project management

Title: Project delay analysis of highrise building project in Jakarta
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Salim, W.N., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Sujana, C.M., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Highrise building construction in Jakarta continues to increase over time. The complex characteristics of highrise building work present challenges for contractors to be able to complete projects on time. Many factors cause delays in highrise building projects and these factors differ from every country. A survey used questionnaires that have conducted in Jakarta, Indonesia obtained ten dominant factors which were then grouped into two main variables: (1) changes in the scope of work and (2) weak planning and controlling. Changes in the scope of work have a direct impact on changes in project costs. The development of the contractor team's ability to coordinate and communicate with other parties involved in construction, likewise the development of the contractor team's ability to plan is expected to overcome project delays in highrise building projects. Improving the capability of the contractor team project is needed to support sustainable competitiveness in the construction sector. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: analysis factor; contractor; highrise building; project delay
Index Keywords: Buildings; Construction industry; Contractors; Surveys; analysis factor; Complex characteristics; Construction sectors; Dominant factor; High rise building; High-rise building constructions; Planning and controlling; Project delays; Construction

Authors: Safira D., Safitri F., Kamal H., Meilani, Sujana C.M., Andika A.
Title: Time accelaration of offshore EPC project using FMEA, FTA, CPM and crashing method at PT XYZ
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Safira, D., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Safitri, F., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kamal, H., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Meilani, Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Sujana, C.M., Civil Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Andika, A., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The pipe instalation of offshore EPC project has high risk of cost overruns due to the uncertainty of weather, human errors, pipe fabriction process, etc. All of those risks will cause the project delay. The optimiziation of risk based project scheduling can reduce the risks. Risk management can be optimized with combining some methods, such as Failure Mode and Effect Analysis (FMEA), Fault Tree Analysis (FTA), Critical Path Method (CPM) and Crashing Project method. The combination of these methods are used to do the data analysis in order to reduce the project total duration. Based on analysis using FMEA, FTA, CPM and crashing project method, the total of project duration can be reduced from 499 days to 489 days with Rp. 6.822.472,- as the additional cost of workers. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: Crashing Project method; Critical Path Method; Failure Mode and Effect Analysis; Fault Tree Analysis
Index Keywords: Critical path analysis; Offshore oil well production; Offshore pipelines; Risk assessment; Risk management; Turnaround time; Additional costs; Critical path method; Failure mode and effect analysis; Fault tree analyses (FTA); Project delays; Project duration; Project methods; Project scheduling; Fault tree analysis
